bio: Usain Bolt, OJ, CD, (born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican sprinter. He is the first person to hold both the 100 metres and 200 metres world records since fully automatic time became mandatory. He also holds the world record as a part of the 4 × 100 metres relay. Often described as the fastest man in history, he is the reigning Olympic champion in these three events, as well as the reigning world champion. He is the first person to hold three Olympic gold medals in sprinting events at the same Olympics, and the first to win six Olympic gold medals in sprinting. He is also the only person to win World Championships 100 metres and 200 metres titles in consecutive years (2009–2011).

bio: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science fiction sitcom created by Justin Roiland and Dan Harmon for Cartoon Network's nighttime Adult Swim programming block. The series follows the misadventures of cynical mad scientist Rick Sanchez and his good-hearted but fretful grandson Morty Smith, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional adventures. The series originated from an animated parody of Back to the Future that Roiland created in 2007, and turned into a series of short films that he and Harmon developed for Channel 101. In 2012, the duo shopped the series to networks and eventually sold it to Cartoon Network.

bio: Geraldine Chaplin (born 31 July 1944) is a British-American actress and singer. She is the daughter of Charlie Chaplin and Oona O'Neill, and the sister of Michael Chaplin. Chaplin has been nominated for an Academy Award three times, and won the award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in the 1985 film A Room with a View. She has also appeared in many other films, including The Age of Innocence (1993), Doctor Zhivago (1965), The Last Tycoon (1976), The Magus (1968), and The Last Temptation of Christ (1988).

bio: The Reader (2008 film) is a 2008 drama film directed by Stephen Daldry and written by David Hare, based on the 1995 German novel of the same name by Bernhard Schlink. The film stars Kate Winslet, Ralph Fiennes, and David Kross. It was released in the United States on November 6, 2008, by The Weinstein Company. The film is about a 15-year-old boy who has a brief affair with an older woman and then becomes involved in her trial after she is charged with war crimes. The film is loosely based on the novel, with some characters and events being changed or omitted.

bio: Emily Ratajkowski (born June 7, 1991) is an American actress and model. Born to American parents in London and raised primarily in California, she began acting as a child and continued to model as a teenager. She rose to prominence in 2013 after appearing in the music video for Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines", which became the number one song of the year in several countries and attracted controversy over its sexual content. Ratajkowski appeared in several films in 2014 and was named to the Forbes list of the World's Highest-Paid Models. She has also appeared on the cover of several magazines, including the March 2015 issue of British GQ.

bio: The Bridges of Madison County (film) is a 1995 American romantic drama film directed by Clint Eastwood, based on the best-selling 1992 novel of the same name by Robert James Waller. It stars Meryl Streep and Clint Eastwood, with supporting performances by Annie Corley, Victor Slezak, and Jim Haynie. The film depicts the four-day affair between a housewife and a National Geographic photographer who is passing through her town. The film was released on December 22, 1995, by Warner Bros. Pictures and grossed over $100 million worldwide. It received mixed reviews from critics, who praised Streep's performance but criticized Eastwood's directing and the lack of chemistry between the two leads.

bio: Tom Hiddleston (born 9 February 1981) is an English actor. He is known for playing Loki in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, beginning with Thor (2011), and for portraying Henry Cavill's character, Jonathan Pine, in the AMC spy thriller series The Night Manager (2016). He has also appeared in the films Midnight in Paris (2011), War Horse (2011), The Deep Blue Sea (2011), Thor: The Dark World (2013), Thor: Ragnarok (2017), Kong: Skull Island (2017), and Avengers: Infinity War (2018). Hiddleston has received a Primetime Emmy Award nomination and three Golden Globe Award nominations for his work in The Night Manager.

bio: Baahubali: The Beginning is a 2015 Indian epic action drama film directed by S. S. Rajamouli. It was produced by Shobu Yarlagadda and Prasad Devineni under the banner Arka Media Works. The film stars Prabhas, Rana Daggubati, Anushka Shetty, Tamannaah Bhatia, Ramya Krishnan, Sathyaraj and Nassar in the lead roles. The film's score and soundtrack are composed by M. M. Keeravani. The film was shot in Telugu and Tamil languages simultaneously. The film was dubbed into Hindi as Baahubali: The Beginning. The film was released on 10 July 2015, in Telugu, Tamil and Hindi. The film was dubbed in Malayalam as Baahubali: The Beginning.

bio: Newspaper is a medium of communication that is published every day, weekly, bi-weekly, or monthly. Newspapers may be printed on relatively inexpensive, low-grade paper, or may be printed on higher-quality paper. The news media in a society play a variety of roles, including informing citizens about current events, and recording the history of the time. Newspapers provide information on current events, including political events, crime, business, sports, arts, and culture. The news media also helps shape the agenda of the nation.

bio: Harry Potter (film series) is a film series based on the Harry Potter novels by author J. K. Rowling. The series is distributed by Warner Bros. and consists of eight fantasy films, beginning with Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001) and culminating with Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2 (2011). The first six films were written by Steve Kloves and the last two films were written by Steve Kloves and J. K. Rowling. The series is the most successful in film history, earning over $7.7 billion worldwide and garnering ten Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture for the first film. The series is distributed in the United Kingdom by Columbia Pictures, and in the United States by Warner Bros. Pictures. The films have also been broadcast on the NBC network in the United States.

bio: Brad Pitt (born December 18, 1963) is an American actor and producer. He has received multiple awards and nominations, including an Academy Award as producer under his own company Plan B Entertainment. He first gained recognition as a cowboy hitchhiker in the road movie Thelma & Louise (1991). Cult films are often low-budget films produced by independent filmmakers or studios, and often have a very small or non-existent theatrical release. They are sometimes distributed through bootleg or underground channels. Cult films are often referred to as "trash films", and are sometimes associated with exploitation films.

bio: Evan Rachel Wood (born September 7, 1987) is an American actress and musician. She made her acting debut in the 1994 film Digging to China, and received critical acclaim for her performance in the independent drama Thirteen (2003), for which she received a nomination for the Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama. She went on to star in the black comedy Pretty Persuasion (2005), the horror film The Messengers (2007), the romantic comedy The Ugly Truth (2009), the horror film The Conspirator (2010), the science fiction film Mars Needs Moms (2011), and the romantic comedy-drama All Is Bright (2013). Wood has also voiced the character of Vesper Lynd in the James Bond video games Quantum of Solace (2008) and Blood Stone (2010).

bio: The Twilight Saga (film series) is a series of five romantic fantasy films based on the four novels by American author Stephenie Meyer. The series is directed by Catherine Hardwicke and Chris Weitz, with the latter directing the third installment. The series stars Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson, and Taylor Lautner, and tells the story of Bella Swan (Stewart), a teenager who moves to Forks, Washington, and falls in love with a 104-year-old vampire named Edward Cullen (Pattinson), and his family, including his brother, Jasper Hale (Lautner).

bio: One More Light is the seventh studio album by American rock band Linkin Park, released on May 19, 2017, through Warner Bros. Records. It was the band's first album to feature vocalist Mike Shinoda as the only rapper and was the first Linkin Park album to be released without founding member and lead rapper, Mike Shinoda. The album was recorded from 2015 to 2017. The band worked with a variety of producers, including Rick Rubin, Andrew Bolooki, Mike Shinoda, and Brad Delson. The album features guest vocals from Pusha T, Stormzy, and Kiiara.

bio: Mango is a fruit of the genus Mangifera, consisting of numerous tropical fruiting trees in the flowering plant family Anacardiaceae. The mango is native to the Indian subcontinent where it is believed to have originated in the Indus valley of Pakistan and northwestern India. It has been cultivated since ancient times from where it has spread worldwide to become one of the most common fruits cultivated in the tropics.

bio: Social justice is a concept of fair and just relations between the individual and society. This is measured by the explicit and tacit terms for the distribution of wealth, opportunities for personal activity, and social privileges. In Western as well as in older Asian cultures, the concept of social justice has often referred to the process of ensuring that individuals fulfill their societal roles and receive what was their due from society. In the current global grassroots movements for social justice, the emphasis has been on the breaking of barriers that stand in the way of the exercise of human rights by diverse groups of people, an important theme chosen by the United Nations for its annual International Day of Social Justice.

bio: The Land Before Time is a 1988 American animated adventure musical film directed and co-produced by Don Bluth and executive produced by Steven Spielberg, George Lucas, Kathleen Kennedy, and Frank Marshall. The executive producers hired Thomas N. Meehan and Nora K. Alter to write the story and the screenplay. The film stars the voices of Gabriel Damon, Candace Hutson, Judith Barsi and Will Ryan with narration provided by Pat Hingle. It focuses on a group of young dinosaurs who live in the Great Valley, an area that is populated by various species of dinosaurs. After the group's mother is killed by a Tyrannosaurus, the dinosaur children are separated from their families and forced to fend for themselves. The group of dinosaurs embark on a journey to the legendary "Great Valley" in order to find food and safety.

bio: Ryan Gosling (born Ryan Thomas Gosling; November 12, 1980) is a Canadian actor and musician. He began his career as a child star on the Disney Channel's The Mickey Mouse Club (1993–1995) and went on to appear in other family entertainment programs, including Are You Afraid of the Dark? (1995) and Goosebumps (1996). He made his film debut in the drama The Slaughter Rule (2002), and continued to work in television and film, including the drama Young Hercules (1998) and the comedy-drama Remember the Titans (2000). He gained widespread recognition for starring in the romantic drama The Notebook (2004). Gosling went on to star in the neo-noir thriller Stay (2005), the drama Half Nelson (2006), the romantic comedy-drama Lars and the Real Girl (2007), the drama Blue Valentine (2010), and the political thriller The Ides of March (2011).

bio: R. Kelly (born Robert Sylvester Kelly; January 8, 1967) is an American singer-songwriter, record producer, and former professional basketball player. A native of Chicago, Illinois, Kelly began his career in 1991, releasing his first album, Born into the 90's. He rose to mainstream prominence in 1993 with the release of his second album, 12 Play. Kelly is the leader of a vocal group called Public Announcement. He has released a total of 14 studio albums, including TP.3 Reloaded and Write Me Back. Kelly has written, produced, and remixed tracks and albums for several artists, including Aaliyah, Celine Dion, Michael Jackson, and Lady Gaga.

bio: Robert Browning (7 May 1812 – 12 December 1889) was an English poet and playwright whose mastery of the dramatic monologue made him one of the foremost Victorian poets. His poems are known for their irony, characterization, dark humor, social commentary, historical settings, and challenging vocabulary and syntax. Early in his life, Browning suffered from a nervous disorder which caused him to lose his hearing. The loss of his hearing did not, however, affect his writing. Browning wrote his most famous dramatic monologues in the 1840s. His later works are considered to be more serious, and some are regarded as classics.

bio: The Shape of Water is a 2017 American romantic fantasy film directed by Guillermo del Toro and written by del Toro and Vanessa Taylor. It stars Sally Hawkins, Michael Shannon, Richard Jenkins, Doug Jones, Michael Stuhlbarg, and Octavia Spencer. Set in 1962 Cold War-era Baltimore, the film is a fairy tale inspired by the romance between a mute janitor and an amphibious creature held captive in a government laboratory. The film premiered at the Venice Film Festival on September 1, 2017, where it won the Golden Lion. It was theatrically released in the United States on December 8, 2017, by Fox Searchlight Pictures.

bio: The Catalyst is the fourth studio album by American rock band Linkin Park. It was released on May 18, 2010, by Warner Bros. Records. The album is a follow-up to the band's third studio album, Minutes to Midnight (2007). The album was written and recorded between 2009 and 2010. It was produced by Rick Rubin and Mike Shinoda. The album was promoted with the release of its lead single, "The Catalyst", which was released on March 16, 2010. The album's second single, "Waiting for the End", was released on May 10, 2010. The album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, selling 223,000 copies in its first week. The album also debuted at number one in Canada and Australia. It was the band's fourth number one album in the United States, and the band's first number one album in Canada and Australia.

bio: Blue-ringed octopus (genus Hapalochlaena) is a venomous marine cephalopod in the family Octopodidae, and is one of the world's most venomous animals. It is named for the blue rings that are present on its body, but this feature is not always present. The blue rings are usually only visible when the octopus is alarmed or threatened. The blue-ringed octopus is found in the coastal waters of the Indian and Pacific Oceans, from Japan to Australia.

bio: Tyra Banks (born December 4, 1973) is an American model, television personality, producer, author, actress, singer and businesswoman. She first became famous as a model, appearing twice on the cover of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue and working for Victoria's Secret as one of their original Angels. Banks then began acting, starring in the high-profile films Higher Learning (1995), Love & Basketball (2000) and Coyote Ugly (2000). She later co-starred in the television series Gossip Girl (2007–2012) and America's Next Top Model (2003–2015). She has been a talk show host since 2005, and has been a producer since 2010.

bio: Philip V of Spain (Spanish: Felipe V; 19 December 1683 – 9 July 1746) was King of Spain from 1 November 1700 until his abdication on 15 January 1724. He was the first member of the House of Bourbon to rule Spain. Philip V was born in Versailles, France, as the second son of Louis, Duke of Anjou and Marie-Adélaïde of Savoy. His father was a younger brother of King Louis XIV of France, and his mother was the eldest daughter of Victor Amadeus II, Duke of Savoy. Philip's elder brother, Louis, died in 1712, leaving Philip as heir to the throne of Spain.

bio: Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a sovereign city-state and island country in Southeast Asia. Founded as a British trading colony in 1819, since independence it has become one of the world's most prosperous countries and boasts the world's busiest port. In terms of GDP per capita, it is one of the world's wealthiest nations. Singapore has a highly developed market economy, based historically on extended entrepôt trade. Along with Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan, it is one of the original Four Asian Tigers, but has surpassed its peers in terms of GDP per capita. The country has also been identified as a newly industrialised economy.

bio: South Park is an American animated sitcom created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone for the Comedy Central television network. Intended for mature audiences, the show has become infamous for its crude sense of humor that makes fun of the week's topical events. The show is known for its surreal, often dark humor that lampoons a wide range of topics. The ongoing narrative revolves around four boys—Stan Marsh, Kyle Broflovski, Eric Cartman, and Kenny McCormick—and their bizarre adventures in and around the titular Colorado town. The show makes use of a wide range of animation styles, including cutout animation, stop motion, computer animation, and traditional animation.

bio: Three Days of the Condor is a 1975 American political thriller film directed by Sydney Pollack and starring Robert Redford, Faye Dunaway, and Max von Sydow. It was adapted by Lorenzo Semple Jr. and David Rayfiel from the 1974 novel Six Days of the Condor by James Grady and screenwriter David Rayfiel, who had been hired by the CIA to write the screenplay. The film was a box office success, and it was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.

bio: French Open, also called Roland-Garros, French Open, or Tournoi de Roland-Garros, annual tennis tournament held at the Stade Roland-Garros in Paris. The French Open is the second of the four annual Grand Slam tournaments, and it is the only major played on clay. The event is held in May and June, and the men's singles final is always held on the Sunday before the second Monday in June. The French Open is the only Grand Slam tournament to be held on clay. The French Open is the only major tournament to be held in the same location every year.

bio: Ryan O'Neal (born Charles Patrick Ryan O'Neal; April 20, 1941) is an American actor, screenwriter, and former football player. O'Neal's career began in 1960 with a leading role in the film The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond. He received Academy Award nominations for Best Supporting Actor for Peyton Place (1957) and What's Up, Doc? (1972), and won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for Love Story (1970). His other notable films include The Longest Day (1962), The Sand Pebbles (1966), Barbarella (1968), The Main Event (1979), and Tough Guys (1986). He starred in the television series Banning (1969–1973) and had a recurring role in the series Tales from the Crypt (1989–1996).

bio: Lupe Fiasco (born Wasalu Muhammad Jaco; February 19, 1982) is an American rapper, record producer, entrepreneur, and community advocate from Chicago, Illinois. He rose to fame in 2006 following the success of his debut album, Food & Liquor, which was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Food & Liquor. His follow-up album, Lupe Fiasco's Food & Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album, Pt. 1, was released in 2012. He is also known for his mixtapes, including 1st (2006), Friend of the People (2005), and LupE.N.D (2006).

bio: John Lennon (born John Winston Ono Lennon; 9 October 1940 – 8 December 1980) was an English singer, songwriter, musician, and peace activist who co-founded the Beatles, the most commercially successful band in the history of popular music. With fellow member Paul McCartney, he formed one of the most celebrated songwriting partnerships of the 20th century. Born and raised in Liverpool, Lennon became involved in the skiffle craze as a teenager; his first band, the Quarrymen, evolved into the Beatles in 1960. When the group disbanded in 1970, Lennon pursued a solo career that produced the albums John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band and Imagine, and songs such as "Give Peace a Chance" and "Imagine". After his marriage to Yoko Ono in 1969, he changed his name to John Ono Lennon. Lennon disengaged himself from the music business in 1975 to raise his infant son Sean, but re-emerged with Ono in 1980 with the new album Double Fantasy. He was murdered three weeks after its release.

bio: Romelu Lukaku (born 13 May 1993) is a Belgian professional footballer who plays as a striker for Premier League club Chelsea and the Belgium national team. Lukaku started his career at Anderlecht, before signing for Chelsea in 2011. He spent two seasons on loan at West Bromwich Albion and one at Everton, before returning to Chelsea in 2014. Lukaku won the Premier League Golden Boot in 2017–18, after scoring 25 goals. He has been Belgium's top scorer in the 2014 and 2018 FIFA World Cups, and the 2016 and 2018 UEFA European Championships. He was named the Belgian Footballer of the Year for three consecutive years between 2015 and 2017.

bio: David Beckham, OBE (born 2 May 1975) is an English former professional footballer, the current president and co-owner of Inter Miami CF and co-owner of Salford City. He played for Manchester United, Preston North End, Real Madrid, Milan, LA Galaxy, Paris Saint-Germain and the England national team, for which he held the appearance record for an outfield player until 2016. He is the first English player to win league titles in four countries: England, Spain, the United States and France. He announced his retirement in May 2013 after a 20-year career, during which he won 19 major trophies. He made 115 appearances for the England national team between 1996 and 2009, including appearing at three FIFA World Cup tournaments and in three UEFA European Championship tournaments.

bio: Twitter is an online social networking service that enables users to send and read short 140-character messages called "tweets". It was created in March 2006 by Jack Dorsey, Evan Williams, Biz Stone, and Noah Glass and launched in July of that year. bio: Alien: Covenant is a 2017 science fiction horror film directed by Ridley Scott and written by Jack Paglen and Michael Green. It is the sixth installment in the Alien film series, and the sequel to the 2012 film Prometheus. It stars Michael Fassbender, Katherine Waterston, Billy Crudup, Danny McBride, Demián Bichir, Carmen Ejogo, Jussie Smollett, Amy Seimetz, Callie Hernandez, Nathaniel Dean, Alexander England, and Benjamin Rigby. The film follows the crew of a colony ship who discover what they think is an uncharted paradise, but is actually a dark, dangerous world.

He has been nominated for an Academy Award, a Screen Actors Guild Award, and a Golden Globe Award.

bio: Kim Basinger (born December 8, 1953) is an American actress and former fashion model. She was a popular model before making her film debut in 1981's Hard Country, and gained recognition for her portrayal of Bond girl Domino Petachi in Never Say Never Again (1983). Basinger's breakthrough came in 1989 with her portrayal of Charlie Chaplin's wife, Lita Grey, in The Joker Is Wild, which earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress.

bio: David Bowie (8 January 1947 – 10 January 2016) was an English singer-songwriter and actor. A leading figure in the music industry, Bowie was known for his distinctive voice and the intellectual depth and eclecticism of his work. He was also regarded as a pioneer, particularly for his work in the 1970s. Shortly after releasing his 25th album, Blackstar, on 8 January 2016, Bowie died of liver cancer at his home in New York City.

bio: Emmanuel Adebayor (born 26 February 1984) is a Togolese professional footballer who plays as a forward for Turkish club İstanbul Başakşehir and the Togolese national team. Adebayor began his career in his native Togo, playing for AS Semassi. He joined the Metz youth academy in France in 1999, and was promoted to the senior team in 2000. He moved to Monaco in 2003, and later to Arsenal in 2006. Adebayor won the Premier League in his first season with the club, and the FA Cup in 2007. He won the FA Community Shield in 2004 and 2006. In 2008, he joined Manchester City, where he won the Premier League, FA Cup and League Cup. He was part of the City team that won the 2011 FA Cup Final, his fifth FA Cup triumph. In 2013, he joined Tottenham Hotspur, winning the Football League Cup in 2015. He was part of the team that won the 2015 African Cup of Nations, scoring the opening goal in the final. He joined İstanbul Başakşehir in 2019.

bio: IO Theater is a non-profit theater company in Chicago, Illinois, United States. Founded in 2000 by Jon Martinez and David Kodeski, IO Theater is the first theater company to open in Chicago's West Loop neighborhood. In 2004, the company moved to its current location at 1501 W. Division Street. The company's name is a reference to the International Olympic Committee.

bio: Starbucks Corporation is an American multinational chain of coffeehouses and roastery reserves headquartered in Seattle, Washington. It was founded in 1971 by Jerry Baldwin, Gordon Bowker, and Zev Siegl in Seattle, Washington. The company is seen to have played a significant role in the demise of small, independent coffee shops in the United States. As of 2018, the company operates 28,218 locations worldwide.

bio: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (Marathi: बाळ गंगाधर तिळक; 23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920) was an Indian nationalist, social reformer and writer of the Indian Independence Movement. He was also known as Lokmanya Tilak or "The Great Soul". He was one of the first Indian nationalists to support complete political independence, and he was one of the first nationalist leaders to use the word Swaraj as a slogan. He is remembered as the "Father of the Indian Unrest" for his role in awakening Indian nationalism during the Indian Independence Movement. He was a leader of the Home Rule Movement in colonial India.

bio: Renaissance is a French term for "rebirth", first used in English in the 1830s. The word has several meanings in different historical and cultural contexts. In its broadest sense, Renaissance is a European intellectual movement that was originally a revival of Classical learning and wisdom, and occurred from the 14th to the 17th century. This period is conventionally considered to have begun in Italy in the Late Medieval period, lasting from the 14th to early 17th century, with the Renaissance spreading to the rest of Europe by the 16th century. The Renaissance began as a cultural movement in Italy in the Late Medieval period and later spread to the rest of Europe. This period saw the revival of intellectual thought and wisdom following the Middle Ages, manifested in art, politics, science, religion, and philosophy. The period is considered by many historians to be the "bridge" between the Middle Ages and modern history.

bio: Agatha Christie, Lady Mallowan, DBE (15 September 1890 – 12 January 1976) was an English crime novelist, short story writer and playwright. She also wrote romances, non-fiction, and a series of 14 short stories under the name Mary Westmacott. Her work has been translated into over 100 languages and, according to the Guinness World Records, she is the best-selling novelist of all time. Her novels have sold roughly four billion copies, and her estate claims that her work comes third in the rankings of the world's most-widely published books, after only the Bible and Shakespeare.

bio: Fight Club is a 1999 American film based on the 1996 novel of the same name by Chuck Palahniuk. The film was directed by David Fincher, and stars Brad Pitt, Edward Norton, and Helena Bonham Carter. Norton plays an unnamed protagonist struggling with insomnia, and an obsession with material objects and a false sense of masculinity. After attending support groups, he meets Tyler Durden (Pitt), an anarchist who lives a life of hedonism. The protagonist becomes increasingly enamored with Tyler and his way of life, and they form a fight club together.

He is best known for his role as a temporary deputy marshal in the events leading up to and following the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral. His autopsy revealed tuberculosis, which caused his death at the age of 36.

bio: Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science-fiction adventure comedy film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film Back to the Future and the second installment in the Back to the Future trilogy. The film stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Lea Thompson, Thomas F. Wilson, and Elisabeth Shue. The plot picks up exactly where the first film left off, with Marty McFly (Fox) and Doc Brown (Lloyd) having returned to 1985 after saving Marty's parents' romance in 1955. Marty and Doc travel to 2015 to prevent Marty's son from being murdered by Biff Tannen (Wilson). The film is an American-Canadian production, and was shot in California and Ontario.

bio: Charles Marie de La Condamine (French: [ʃaʁl maʁi də la kɔ̃damin]; 28 October 1701 – 4 February 1774) was a French mathematician, geographer, and explorer. He was a member of the French scientific mission to South America from 1735 to 1744. He is best known for his participation in the French scientific mission to South America. He was one of the four scientists who made the first accurate measurement of the length of a degree of latitude at the Equator.

bio: Edgar Allan Poe (born Edgar Poe; January 19, 1809 – October 7, 1849) was an American writer, poet, editor, and literary critic, considered part of the American Romantic Movement. Best known for his tales of mystery and the macabre, Poe was one of the earliest American practitioners of the short story, and is generally considered the inventor of the detective fiction genre. He is further credited with contributing to the emerging genre of science fiction. He was the first well-known American writer to try to earn a living through writing alone, resulting in a financially difficult life and career.

bio: Gerard Butler (born 13 November 1969) is a Scottish actor who has appeared on film, stage, and television. A trained lawyer, Butler turned to acting in the mid-1990s with small roles in productions such as Mrs Brown (1997), the James Bond film Tomorrow Never Dies (1997), and the historical drama Attila (2001). He first gained recognition for his role in the 2000 drama film Reign of Fire. Butler subsequently appeared in a series of films, including the epic historical drama Alexander (2004), the fantasy adventure film The Phantom of the Opera (2004), the epic disaster film Dante's Peak (1997), the romantic comedy P.S. I Love You (2007), and the romantic comedy The Ugly Truth (2009).

bio: Northeast megalopolis is a proposed megalopolis which would include the cities of New York City, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, D.C., and Boston. The concept of the Northeast megalopolis was first proposed in 1969 by Harvard professor and urban planner, Edwin O. Wilson. Wilson's concept included a number of other cities such as Providence, Hartford, New Haven, Newark, Trenton, and Pittsburgh.

bio: Transformers: Dark of the Moon is a 2011 American science fiction action film directed by Michael Bay, based on the toy line, and the third installment in the Transformers film series. The film is the sequel to 2009's Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen and the third installment in the live-action film series. It was produced by Steven Spielberg and Bay's production company Platinum Dunes, and was written by Ehren Kruger, with the story based on the Transformers toy line. The film stars Shia LaBeouf, Josh Duhamel, John Turturro, Tyrese Gibson, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, Patrick Dempsey, Kevin Dunn, Julie White, and John Malkovich, with Leonard Nimoy reprising his role from the first film as well as Peter Cullen, who voices Optimus Prime. The film was released in the United States on June 28, 2011, and was met with generally negative reviews.

bio: Audrey Horne is a Norwegian hard rock band formed in 1997 in Bergen, Norway. The band was formed by former members of the band The Animal. The band's name is a reference to the character Audrey Horne from the film Twin Peaks. The band's music has been described as "hard rock with a touch of prog". The band has released five studio albums: Blackout (2002), Overstay (2005), Youngblood (2008), Pure Heavy (2012), and Bliss (2018).

bio: The Host (2013 film) is a 2013 South Korean monster film directed by Bong Joon-ho, starring Song Kang-ho, Byun Hee-bong, Park Hae-il, Bae Doona, and Park Hyuk-kwon. It is an adaptation of the 2008 novel of the same name by author Shin Kyung-sook, and is a co-production between South Korea and Japan. The film follows a monster that emerges from a sewer in Seoul and attacks people, as well as a family who are separated from each other after the monster attacks. The Host was theatrically released in South Korea on 29 March 2013. It was released in the United States on 22 March 2013.

bio: The Twilight Saga (film series) is a series of five romance fantasy films based on Stephenie Meyer's four-book Twilight series. The films star Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson, and tell the story of Bella Swan (Stewart), a teenage girl who moves to Forks, Washington, and falls in love with a 104-year-old vampire named Edward Cullen (Pattinson). The series is produced by Maverick Films, Temple Hill Entertainment, and Summit Entertainment. The films are directed by Catherine Hardwicke, Chris Weitz, and David Slade. The first film, Twilight, was released on November 21, 2008, and the final installment, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 2, was released on November 16, 2012.

bio: Kangana Ranaut (born 23 March 1987) is an Indian actress who works in Hindi films. She has received four National Film Awards, four Filmfare Awards, and an award at the Cannes Film Festival. She has featured in Forbes India's Celebrity 100 list since 2014, and was ranked 99th in the World's 100 Most Powerful Women list by Forbes in 2019. Born to a poor family in Bhambla, Himachal Pradesh, Ranaut moved to Delhi to pursue a modelling career. She made her acting debut in the 2006 thriller Gangster, for which she won the Filmfare Award for Best Female Debut. She followed it with starring roles in Woh Lamhe (2006), Life in a... Metro (2007), Fashion (2008), and Raaz: The Mystery Continues (2009).

bio: Soundgarden was an American rock band formed in Seattle, Washington in 1984 by singer and guitarist Chris Cornell, lead guitarist Kim Thayil, and bassist Hiro Yamamoto. (2004), When in Rome (2010), Life as We Know It (2010), Safe Haven (2013), Transformers: Dark of the Moon (2011), and Transformers: The Last Knight (2017).

bio: Basic Instinct is a 1992 American neo-noir erotic thriller film directed by Paul Verhoeven and written by Joe Eszterhas, and starring Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone. The film follows San Francisco police detective Nick Curran (Douglas) as he investigates the brutal murder of a mysterious woman, Catherine Tramell (Stone), who becomes his main suspect. The film was a commercial success, grossing over $115 million worldwide.

bio: Plato (Greek: Πλάτων Plátōn; 428/427 or 424/423 BC – 348/347 BC) was a Greek philosopher, mathematician, writer of philosophical dialogues, and founder of the Academy in Athens, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world. Along with his mentor, Socrates, and his student, Aristotle, Plato helped to lay the foundations of Western philosophy and science. Alfred North Whitehead once noted: "the safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato." In addition to being a founding figure in Western philosophy, Plato is also one of the most influential sources of religious, philosophical, and political ideas in the West, and his influence on western thought is considered to be second only to that of Jesus Christ.

bio: Bruno Mars (born Peter Gene Hernandez; October 8, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, record producer, and dancer. He is known for his stage performances, retro showmanship and for performing in a wide range of musical styles, including pop, rock, funk, soul, and reggae. Mars is accompanied by his band, The Hooligans, who play a variety of instruments such as electric guitar, bass, piano, keyboards, drums, and horns, and also serve as backup singers. Mars is of Filipino descent.

bio: Daniel Craig (born 2 March 1968) is an English actor. He trained at the National Youth Theatre and graduated from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in 1991, before beginning his career on stage. His film debut was in the drama The Power of One (1992), and he gained popularity in the BBC television series Our Friends in the North (1996) and the film Elizabeth (1998), for which he received a BAFTA nomination for Best Actor in a Supporting Role. He also starred in the films Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001), Road to Perdition (2002), and Sylvia (2003).

bio: Nikita (TV series) is an American action-thriller television series based on the French film La Femme Nikita (1990). The series was created by Craig Silverstein, who served as showrunner and executive producer. The series stars Maggie Q, as Nikita, a trained assassin seeking redemption after being rescued from death row by a secret U.S. government agency. The series premiered on September 9, 2010, on The CW and ended on December 27, 2013, after four seasons and 80 episodes. The series is the first American television series to be filmed in Canada.

bio: Republic of Ireland is a country in Western Europe occupying about five-sixths of the island of Ireland. It is a unitary parliamentary republic with an elected president serving as head of state. The capital and largest city is Dublin, which is located on the east coast. Ireland is a unitary sovereign state comprising the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The island of Ireland is separated by the Irish Sea and the North Channel from Great Britain, from which it was part of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland until 1922. Ireland is the second-largest island in the British Isles, the third-largest in Europe, and the twentieth-largest on Earth.
